newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-ALBERT BELLE ADMITS TO GAMBLING LOSSES.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-ALBERT BELLE ADMITS TO GAMBLING LOSSES.

text.p: Former Cleveland Indians home run basher Albert Belle admitted under oath in a legal deposition that he lost up to $40,000 gambling on pro football and college basketball games, a newspaper reported Wednesday.

Belle, who left the Indians this offseason to sign a $55 million free agent contract with the Chicago White Sox, made the admission Tuesday in a lawsuit filed over a 1995 incident in which he chased a group of boys that threw eggs at his house, the Cleveland Plain-Dealer reported Wednesday.
Belle's attorney, Jose Feliciano, told the newspaper that his client bet only on football and basketball and not on baseball games.
"Albert, like many other players, does bet on games outside of his own sport," Feliciano said.
Baseball personnel are strictly prohibited from betting on Major League games and could be banned for life if bets were placed on games involving their own team.
A Major League Baseball spokesman declined to comment on the report.
White Sox vice president of major league operations Ron Schueler issued a statement saying: "We do not have any information at this time so we are not in a position to comment."
Belle made the gambling admission while being questioned by an attorney for one of the boys in the egg throwing incident, the Plain-Dealer reported.

A local court found the four boys delinquent of criminal mischief last year. But Sandra Abdul-Razzaaq, a guardian of one of the boys, is suing Belle for $850,000 in damages, saying the boy was injured while being chased by Belle in his Ford Explorer.
Cleveland lawyer Richard Lillie, representing the boy, told the Plain-Dealer he was questioning Belle about gambling and other issues as "another way of impeaching his credibility."
Lillie said he also questioned Belle about his well documented temper outbursts, alcoholism treatment and numerous suspensions from baseball.
